image.copyright: Aircraft on display at the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center, the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum's facility at Washington Dulles International Airport, Virginia -- David Sailors/CORBIS

hotspot.desc: On this day in 1846, President Polk signed this institution into law. It includes 19 museums, 9 research facilities, a zoo, and over 136 million items in its collection.
hotspot.query: Can you guess what it is?

hotspot.desc: Are you one of those people who's interested in everything from inaugural gowns to cockroaches, airplanes to fine art?
hotspot.query: There's a TV channel just for you

hotspot.desc: This plane once ferried passengers across the Atlantic faster than the speed of sound.
hotspot.query: Its name was synonymous with glamour

hotspot.desc: Where's the best place to put a new museum devoted entirely to air and space flight?
hotspot.query: In an airport, of course!

image.copyright: Crescent Moon Lake (Yueyaquan), near the ancient silk road city of Dunhuang, Gansu Province, China -- JTB Photo/Japan Travel Bureau/Photolibrary

hotspot.desc: People call this place Echoing Sand Mountain and they say the sand sings.
hotspot.query: How can that be true?

hotspot.desc: Ancient monks carved 492 temples into caves and cliff faces just south of here.
hotspot.query: Visit the Caves of a Thousand Buddhas

hotspot.desc: Silk Road travelers watered their camels and said their prayers here for over 500 years.
hotspot.query: No wonder archaeologists love it so much

hotspot.desc: Would you be relieved to see this oasis after walking hundreds of miles…
hotspot.query: Across the desert?

message.msgtext: See our archive of past images

image.copyright: Hedge maze at Longleat House near the town of Warminster, Wiltshire, England, UK -- Jason Hawkes/Getty Images

hotspot.desc: The world's longest hedge maze was designed without a grid so that it would be more confusing.
hotspot.query: Who would do such a thing?

hotspot.desc: In addition to being a mecca for maze enthusiasts, this place is also home to the first safari park outside of Africa.
hotspot.query: Stroll around the grounds and make yourself at home

hotspot.desc: The craze for hedge mazes evolved from a simple kitchen garden.
hotspot.query: How did they get from there to here?

hotspot.desc: In addition to its hedge maze, this estate boasts a sun maze, a lunar labyrinth, a love labyrinth, and King Arthur's maze.
hotspot.query: Lucky for you, it's easier than ever to find your bearings these days

image.copyright: Two Tree Frogs staring from behind a leaf -- David Aubrey/CORBIS

hotspot.desc: Wide discs at the ends of long fingers and toes give these guys a superior grip.
hotspot.query: Which is handy, if your home is in a tree

hotspot.desc: These tiny creatures are rarely more than four inches long.
hotspot.query: What they lack in size, they make up for in color

hotspot.desc: How could someone eat such cute creatures?
hotspot.query: With a nice aioli sauce is one popular way

hotspot.desc: Have you ever heard of it raining frogs?
hotspot.query: It really happens

image.copyright: Wadi es-Sebua temple, at the edge of Lake Nasser in Lower Nubia, Egypt -- Aldo Pavan/Corbis

hotspot.desc: Two pharaohs built two great temples here over 2,000 years ago.
hotspot.query: How have they held up over the centuries?

hotspot.desc: Where to go for your vacation? Consider this majestic country.
hotspot.query: It was a favorite of both Julius Caesar and Marc Antony.

hotspot.desc: Why do they call this place the Valley of the Lions…
hotspot.query: If no lions live here?

hotspot.desc: The ancient Egyptians built this temple on the banks of the Nile, but it had to be moved in the 1960s…
hotspot.query: When the river was dammed up

message.msgtext: Tour the most famous lost cities
See our archive of past images

image.copyright: Blue Bell Tunicates (Sea squirts) in the waters near Roatan Island, Honduras -- Mike Ricciardi/Photolibrary

hotspot.desc: How do these hermaphroditic critters eat their own brains…
hotspot.query: And live through it?

hotspot.desc: Some think we should explore the oceans instead of space.
hotspot.query: Do a little exploring of your own

hotspot.desc: Do we look as strange to sea creatures…
hotspot.query: As they look to us?

hotspot.desc: You can find these intriguing pods in waters around the world…
hotspot.query: But you can visit these guys in particular right here

image.copyright: A sandy cay off of Útila Island, Honduras -- Mike Ricciardi/Photolibrary

hotspot.desc: One of the most dangerous pirates to work the Spanish Main made his base on a nearby island.
hotspot.query: You may recognize his name

hotspot.desc: If you wanted to search for sunken treasure…
hotspot.query: How would you get started?

hotspot.desc: Why do scuba divers love this place?
hotspot.query: Rare sea creatures and sunken treasure are a good combination

hotspot.desc: According to legend, as many as 5,000 pirates once lived in this chain of islands.
hotspot.query: Avast, ye scoundrels!

image.copyright: The Royal Chapel at the Chateau de Versailles, Versailles, France -- Bertrand Rieger/Hemis/Corbis

hotspot.desc: Why did Europe's longest-reigning monarch build the biggest palace on the continent?
hotspot.query: You can do whatever you like when you're the Sun King

hotspot.desc: It's easy to believe you have a divine right to rule…
hotspot.query: When you live in a place like this

hotspot.desc: Why would someone build 67 staircases in this house?
hotspot.query: Because you can't fit 700 rooms on one floor

hotspot.desc: Even though this palace was built before airplanes were invented…
hotspot.query: It's as lovely from the air as it is on the ground
